result.execSummary:
The defendant Daniel M Alsfelt was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Cocaine/Coca, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(c).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Fine/DNA Surcharge to be paid at the rate of $25.00 per month commencing 6/01/2017 or 7 days Huber for non-payment.
Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided, immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

records.addlTxt: with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Daniel M Alsfelt in court with attorney Jess Martinez.  Melissa J. Zilavy appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case is recalled.  Defendant enters a no contest to count #3.  Court performs plea colloquy and finds defendant guilty of count #3.  Count 4 is dismissed and read-in.  State gives sentencing recommendations.  Attorney Martinez makes statements regarding sentencing.  Defendant makes statement. 

The Defendant was sentenced to the following:

COUNT #3:

FINE:  $505.00 + $200.00 DNA surcharge (to be paid at $25/month, commencing on 6/1/17, alternate is 7 days Huber).

Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided, immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.

Defendant Daniel M Alsfelt in court with attorney Jess Martinez.  Melissa J. Zilavy appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called for continuation of motion to suppress.  Defendant Daniel M. Alsfelt sworn in and gives testimony on behalf of the defense.  Cross-examination by State.  Re-direct by Attorney Martinez.  Defense rests.  Court closes evidentiary portion closed.  
State presents closing arguments.  Defense makes closing statement.  Court denies defendant's motion to suppress.  Case is passed for defense to complete plea and sentencing paperwork.  
  Plea/sentencing hearing scheduled for March 23, 2017 at 03:30 pm.
Motion hearing on March 23, 2017 at 03:00 pm.

Letter dated January 10, 2017, requesting adjournment filed by defendant/defense counsel.

1/11/17 - Judge Ramirez reviewed letter and granted adjournment.
Motion hearing on January 11, 2017 at 03:00 pm.

Defendant Daniel M Alsfelt in court with attorney Nick Martinez.  Melissa J. Zilavy appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Martinez makes statements requesting additional time to subpoena other officers.  Court continues with the motion to take testimony of the witness that is present.  Court takes up initial statements regarding what stipulations the parties have.  State calls witness Officer Jeffry Monreal, sworn in, testified.  Parties continue with arguments.  Court grants request to adjourn the matter.  Motion hearing scheduled for January 11, 2017 at 03:00 pm.
Motion hearing on November 29, 2016 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Daniel M Alsfelt in court with attorney Nick Martinez.  Shawn N Woller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court addresses the motion to suppress filed yesterday.  State has not seen the motion, copy handed to the State by Attorney Martinez.  Attorney Martinez makes statements regarding his motion.  Motion will be heard the morning of the trial, but removes the jury trial from the calendar.
to suppress the fruits of an illegal search, received 11/21/16 from Atty. Martinez
